report.report_text:
[Report de-identified (Safe-harbor compliant) by De-ID v.6.22.07.0]
CONSULTING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[YYY M. ZZZ], D.O.
CHIEF COMPLAINT: Heme in nasogastric tube.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a **AGE[in 60s]-year-old gentleman who has a history of methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus in his foot and necrosis of his fourth and fifth digits. He has had severe hypotension, non Q wave myocardial infarction and type 2 diabetes, dementia, anemia and chronic renal disease. I was asked to evaluate him due to a nasogastric tube with coffee ground emesis. I am unable to get any history from the patient.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Significant for coronary artery disease status post coronary artery bypass graft, ischemic cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction of 45%, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia.
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: Coronary artery bypass graft x3 in 2000, right carotid endarterectomy, tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy, right hip surgery, testicular surgery.
MEDICATIONS: Allopurinol, aspirin, Lipitor, Plavix, Digoxin, Lexapro, Lasix, Glipizide, Imdur, nifedipine, Protonix, OxyContin.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
GENERAL: On exam he is a very ill appearing gentleman, thin, well developed in on acute distress.
NECK: Supple.
LUNGS: Clear.
HEART: Regular rate.
ABDOMEN: Soft, nontender, no rebound, guarding or hepatosplenomegaly.
IMPRESSION: Coffee-ground emesis. At this point I do not feel that this is a significant issue for this gentleman. I am not going to proceed with any further evaluation. We will follow him and continue with proton pump inhibitor therapy.
______________________________ **NAME[YYY M. ZZZ, M. M].
D: **DATE[Jan 20 2008]/ 3:18 P T: **DATE[Jan 22 2008] 12:04 P sn #**ACCESSION-NUMBER[1]/**ID-NUM
**CARBON-COPY
